title: 108_hr482
content: The Act titled "Florida National Forest Land Management Act of 2003" defines terms like "Secretary" and "State" as the Secretary of Agriculture and the State of Florida, respectively. It also addresses the sale or exchange of land. The Secretary has the authority to sell or exchange Federal land in Florida, specifically parcels in Santa Rosa County. This includes tract A-942a (61 acres) and tract A-942b (40 acres). The Secretary has the authority to sell or exchange Federal land in Florida, including tract A-942a (61 acres), tract A-942b (40 acres), tract A-942c (0.59 acres), and tract A-942d (79.90 acres). The Secretary has the authority to sell or exchange Federal land in Florida, including various tracts such as A-942a, A-942b, A-942c, and A-942d, totaling 181.49 acres in Okaloosa County and Ft. Walton. The Secretary has the authority to sell or exchange Federal land in Florida, including tracts in Okaloosa County, Ft. Walton, Crestview, and Liberty County. The tracts range from approximately 12.43 to 40.85 acres in size. The Secretary has the authority to sell or exchange Federal land in Florida, including tracts in Okaloosa County, Ft. Walton, Crestview, and Liberty County. Tracts range from approximately 12.43 to 40.85 acres in size, with specific descriptions of various parcels in different locations such as Bristol, Lake County, and Astor. Tracts in Lake County, Florida, ranging from approximately 15 to 127.2 acres, with specific descriptions including subsurface rights and various sections like SE1/4 NW1/4 and NE1/4 SW1/4. Tracts C-2209, C-2209b, C-2209c, and C-2209d in Lake County, Florida, ranging from approximately 39.41 to 127.2 acres, with specific descriptions including sections like NE1/4 SW1/4 and SE1/4 NW1/4. Tract C-2210 in Marion County, Florida, consists of approximately 30 acres with 20 recreational residential lots on Lake Kerr. Tract C-2210 in Marion County, Florida, includes 20 recreational residential lots on Lake Kerr, totaling around 30 acres. Tract C-2213, located east of Ocala, consists of approximately 15 acres in the F.M. Arrendondo grant. All improvements on the mentioned parcels are also included. The curr_chunk describes the legal description modification and the solicitation of offers for the sale or exchange of land. The Secretary may modify land descriptions based on a survey or public interest. Offers can be solicited subject to terms and conditions. The Secretary may modify land descriptions based on a survey or public interest and solicit offers for the sale or exchange of land. Offers can be rejected if deemed inadequate or not in the public interest. The Secretary can sell land through public or private sale, including auctions, if offers are deemed inadequate or not in the public interest. Real estate brokers can be used, with commissions comparable to industry standards. In land sales or exchanges, the Secretary can use brokers and pay them standard commissions. The Secretary of the Air Force must approve sales of certain parcels. Cash equalization may apply despite certain regulations. The Secretary of the Air Force must approve sales of certain parcels. Cash equalization may apply despite regulations, allowing a cash payment in excess of 25 percent of the Federal land value. Net proceeds from sales or exchanges are deposited in a specific fund. The net proceeds from sales or exchanges under this Act are deposited in the fund established by Public Law 90-171 (16 U.S.C. 484a) for the acquisition of land and reimbursement of costs incurred by the Secretary for the National Forest System in the State. The appropriation is for the acquisition of land and interests in land for inclusion in the National Forest System in the State, as well as reimbursement of costs incurred by the Secretary for land sales and exchanges, including real estate broker commissions. The administration of the acquisition of land and interests in the National Forest System in the State, including reimbursement of costs for land sales and exchanges. Land acquired by the United States under this Act shall be subject to the Weeks Act and administered according to laws applicable to the National Forest System. The land described in section 3(b) is withdrawn from public land laws, mining laws, and mineral leasing laws, except for valid existing rights. The land described in section 3(b) is withdrawn from location, entry, and patent under public land laws, mining laws, and mineral leasing laws.
